channel.title: Installing Car Speakers Myself
channel.description: Alright so I'm getting a 2001 Chevy Cavalier from my sister once I get my license in like a month. The car is technically mine (she has a new one) and we just need to switch the insurance from my dad to me and I'm all set. The car runs awesome because of the way my dad took care of it (It's got over 200k miles on it now). The only problem I've noticed is that my sister blew out the front speakers so they make that crackly sound. I was thinking about buying some new speakers and installing them myself, but I was wondering, since I've legit never worked on a car before should I try and do this on my own and hope I don't fuck up the door panel when I take it off or should I just take the car to a shop and have them install it (if you can do that)? The car doesn't have power windows or locks so I don't need to worry about the connections on the back side of the panel I just don't want to break the plastic on the door frame. So should I try it or no?

item.title: Installing Car Speakers Myself
item.dc:creator: @xryz xryz
item.description:
@xryz wrote:

im not that good with audio or whatever. u might look here and read the replies on different speakers: http://www.amazon.com/gp/search/ref=sr_nr_p_n_size_browse-bin_1?rh=n%3A172282%2Cn%3A!493964%2Cn%3A1077068%2Cn%3A226184%2Cn%3A760560%2Cp_72%3A1248879011%2Cp_36%3A-5000%2Cp_n_size_browse-bin%3A1293701011|1293694011&bbn=760560&ie=UTF8&qid=1314520219&rnid=1293690011#/ref=sr_nr_p_n_size_browse-bin_8?rh=n%3A172282%2Cn%3A!493964%2Cn%3A1077068%2Cn%3A226184%2Cn%3A760560%2Cp_72%3A1248879011%2Cp_36%3A-5000%2Cp_n_size_browse-bin%3A1293694011&bbn=760560&ie=UTF8&qid=1314520380

i looked the size up here: http://www.sonicelectronix.com/chevrolet-cavalier-2001-car-speakers.html if you havent already google or look at some youtube videos to get some better understanding about your car audio set up and stuff, so you will be fairly sure of the outcome. wish you luck. i need to find a job(which will be my first, ive never had a job :/), save up most of that income, and use only what i need, like new plug wires, wipers, im thinking brake pads, and various other things. i would like to upgrade the sound system but it would probably be best if i just waited until i buy a newer car.

Read full topic

item.title: Installing Car Speakers Myself
item.dc:creator: @sp11k3t3ht3rd sp11k3t3ht3rd
item.description:
@sp11k3t3ht3rd wrote:

[quote=“xryz, post:13, topic:412195”]I bought a pair of 6x9 boss 3-way chaos from walmart for ~$35(cant remember but im pretty sure it was around that price). i first had them in my car but my car didnt have enough power from just the headunit. so i put them in my family’s car since it has a stock amp, and their stock rear speaker were blown. I thought they sound nice, especially for the price, it definitely added bass, sound and a little shake. you can check out walmart if you want, afaik the speakers come in pairs, just make sure that is true.

i bought those speakers about a year ago, one sounds like its going bad but i do not believe that is the speakers fault, i believe that the speaker possibly going bad is my fault for how i installed. (the wires were never securely connected, i dont know what the amp output was, my brothers friend liked to have the radio fully turned up, i had a home entertainment system sub also hooked up to the same wire in parallel(didnt do the calculations to see what was going on with the ohms and stuff), and the speaker were exposed to any junk inside the trunk which could have damaged them.)

rear speakers were pretty easy, i have yet to try to remove my front speakers, even though they need replaced, b/c i dont want to mess my door up.[/quote]

Yeah I got interested in getting some new ones because I saw some at Walmart haha

m.dog311:

Yea honestly though, its an easy job, and you’re just going to piss away a good chunk of money taking it to someone.

That’s what I was afraid of. If worst comes to worst and I break the plastic on the door panel, my dad is friends with a mechanic and he’ll just like bolt it back on or some shit like that.

Read full topic

item.title: Installing Car Speakers Myself
item.dc:creator: @xryz xryz
item.description:
@xryz wrote:

I bought a pair of 6x9 boss 3-way chaos from walmart for ~$35(cant remember but im pretty sure it was around that price). i first had them in my car but my car didnt have enough power from just the headunit. so i put them in my family’s car since it has a stock amp, and their stock rear speaker were blown. I thought they sound nice, especially for the price, it definitely added bass, sound and a little shake. you can check out walmart if you want, afaik the speakers come in pairs, just make sure that is true.

i bought those speakers about a year ago, one sounds like its going bad but i do not believe that is the speakers fault, i believe that the speaker possibly going bad is my fault for how i installed. (the wires were never securely connected, i dont know what the amp output was, my brothers friend liked to have the radio fully turned up, i had a home entertainment system sub also hooked up to the same wire in parallel(didnt do the calculations to see what was going on with the ohms and stuff), and the speaker were exposed to any junk inside the trunk which could have damaged them.)

rear speakers were pretty easy, i have yet to try to remove my front speakers, even though they need replaced, b/c i dont want to mess my door up.

Read full topic

item.title: Installing Car Speakers Myself
item.dc:creator: @CoonHunter CoonHunter
item.description:
@CoonHunter wrote:

m.dog311:

It’s a Chevy, which from personal and family experience, are the easiest things to work on. From what I can tell from a few Google searches, you literally pop out a few screws and slide the door panels off. Apparently the clips that CoonHunter is talking about actually just pop right off. Imo, you should have no problems doing it on your own if you’re not an idiot about it (do your research first, make sure you know how to get them off before you attempt it).

They do pop out, but with age they do get brittle. Being a 2001, 10 year old plastic clips that have probably never been touched can break really easy.

Read full topic

I just got a job but I can only keep $100 out of $300 a month (If I make that much) so I can pay for insurance on the car. I get my next check on the 31st which will probably be the check I get to use for myself. I only have like $60 right now.

Read full topic

item.title: Installing Car Speakers Myself
item.dc:creator: @CoonHunter CoonHunter
item.description:
@CoonHunter wrote:

Since you do not know much (and this can easily be screwed up, unlike most people believe) your best bet is to take it to a shop. The plastic door frame has special clips that are made to go on, not off (sounds weird but I have a 98 cavalier sitting in my back yard atm that is waiting on the body kit arrival, put 6x9 speakers in the doors last week). The only real issue is (sometimes) the factory does not use correctly color-coded wires to the speaker, therefore not a easy task to identify positive and negative. Criss-crossing these will give you sound through the speaker, yes, but it won’t sound very good when you turn it up. Many mechanic shops can look up a wiring diagram and easily obtain this.

My suggestion is to get a quote and time first that they think it can be done. If you feel it is way too much for a speaker, you can try it yourself. Just be easy and remember, brute force will solve nothing in this.

Read full topic
